Though many web forms require sophisticated input to lead to 
lots of "deep web" content -- and thus can't be easily crawled
using simple rules -- some forms are so constrained that we
could try crawling the results of submitting them.

Even just considering "method=GET" forms (since we're not yet 
recording http-requests in the detail necessary to log
POSTed values), we could...

- do a default submit on the form, changing no values.
  (We're more likely to want to do this when there are
  no text input-fields, or a small number of already-
  filled-in input-fields.)

- enumerate all permutations of a multi-select menu
  (or radio-button/check-box group), and submit those
  in turn. (We'd only want to do this when the permutations
  are manageable.)

This breaks some long-held assumptions about what a crawler
will do, and thus could trigger webmaster backlash, but also
offers the prospect of getting significant content we'd 
otherwise miss -- since forms are often used to navigate
between a manageable nubmer of set links.

Does Mercator do any aggressive form parsing and submission?
(In at least one situation, it seemed it was looking in
form OPTION VALUE attributes for path-like strings to visit.)

Any other ideas on why we should or shouldn't consider this,
and if we were to implement this behavior, the right way to
do so?

- Gordon
